The Lincoln National Bank, Respondent, v. Jacob S. Butler, Impleaded, Appellant. (City Court of New York

General Term,

November, 1895.) Amended pleadings supersede "the original ones and control, Where one indorses a promissory note payable to another or order prior to its delivery to the payee, in the absence of proof that he intended tó become surety for the maker to the payee, the legal presumption is that he stands in the position of second indorser, and the payee can neither maintain an action.upon the indorsement, nor transfer a right of action ^hereon to a purchaser with notice, except upon assuming responsibility as first indorser. . Aeeeal from judgment in favor of the plaintiff, entered -upon verdict directed by the court. John G. Shaw, for appellant.. Stern cé Jtushmore, for respondent. . * McCabthy, J.

This action was brought against the defendant Butler as indorser upon a promissory note made by one Andrew J. Taylor to the order of James Casey, and thereafter'■ indorsed by the defendant Butler for accommodation of the said Casey, who procured it to- be discounted by the plaintiff.' ■ • .

On the trial of the action, the plaintiff produced the note in suit.

No other testimony was offered by tile plaintiff, the allega- . tion that the indorsement on the note by Butler was for the accommodation of Casey being admitted by the answer.

. The defendant’s counsel moved to .dismiss the complaint, or for á direction, of a verdict in :favor of the defendant, upon the -following grounds:

First. That no cause of action against the defendant. Butler had been shown.

Second. That it had" not been shown that • the indorsement by the defendant Butler was • made for the purpose of • giving credit to the maker with the payee./

*465The motions were denied and the defendant Butler excepted.

The plaintiff’s, counsel moved that a verdict be directed in favor of the plaintiff for the amount of the note, which motion was granted, and the defendant duly excepted.

There has been a mistake as to the facts claimed to have , been conceded by the' amended pleadings. They of course supersede the original and control.

The amended answer, by the second paragraph, denies the very essential facts contained in paragraph 3 of the amended complaint and which plaintiff says was admitted. He is mistaken.

In the absence of proof that Butler’s indorsement was made for the purpose of enabling the maker to obtain credit with the payee, as alleged by the plaintiff in his amended complaint, he stands only in the position of subsequent indorser.

When one indorses a promissory note payable to another or order, prior to its delivery to the payee, in the absence of proof that he indorsed with intent to become surety for the maker to the payee, the legal presumption is that he stands in the position of subsequent indorser, and the payee can neither maintain an action upon the indorsement, nor can he transfer a right of action thereon to a' purchaser with notice, except upon assuming the responsibility of first indorser. Phelps v. Vischer, 50 N. Y. 69 ; Bacon v. Burnham, 37 id. 614; Wyckoff v. Wilson, 30 N. Y. St. Repr. 384; Coulter v. Richmond, 59 N. Y. 481; Bornstein v. Kauffman, 4 Misc. Rep. 83.

Plaintiff, if he had this proof, could have- presented it and thus avoided any further trouble. For this reason judgment must be reversed and a mew trial granted, with costs to the appellant to abide the event.

Coklah and Fitzsimous, JJ., concur.

Judgment reversed and new trial granted, with costs to-appellant to abide event.
